title: Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS)
icd10: C34.90 (Malignant neoplasm of unspecified part of unspecified bronchus or lung - for paraneoplastic LEMS)
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome in adults, including both paraneoplastic (P-LEMS, ~60% associated with small cell lung cancer) and autoimmune (A-LEMS) subtypes. Covers VGCC antibody testing, DELTA-P score calculation for paraneoplastic risk stratification, electrodiagnostic evaluation (repetitive nerve stimulation), cancer screening protocols, symptomatic treatment with 3,4-diaminopyridine, immunotherapy, and long-term monitoring. Excludes myasthenia gravis (separate template), botulism, and congenital myasthenic syndromes.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline before immunotherapy; infection screen; paraneoplastic cytopenias
Renal/hepatic function baseline; electrolytes; pre-treatment assessment
Primary diagnostic test; positive in ~85-90% of LEMS (both P-LEMS and A-LEMS); sensitivity highest for P/Q-type
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative (<0.02 nmol/L); positive confirms LEMS in appropriate clinical context

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: May be co-positive with P/Q-type; less specific but supportive
Paraneoplastic marker highly specific for SCLC (~64% sensitivity in P-LEMS); helps distinguish P-LEMS from A-LEMS
Thyroid disease as autoimmune comorbidity; hypothyroidism worsens weakness
Calcium channel function directly relevant to LEMS pathophysiology

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: MG overlap screen; ~15% of LEMS patients have concurrent MG antibodies
MG overlap; increases sensitivity for coexistent MG
Autoimmune overlap (stiff person syndrome, cerebellar ataxia, type 1 diabetes)
Paraneoplastic marker for SCLC; sensory neuropathy overlap
Paraneoplastic marker; associated with SCLC, chorea, neuropathy
Paraneoplastic marker; stiff person spectrum; breast/lung cancer
Paraneoplastic marker; cerebellar degeneration with SCLC
Screen for prior HBV before rituximab
Baseline before IVIg; monitor on immunosuppression
Immune modulation; deficiency common in autoimmune disease
Tumor marker screen; lung and GI malignancies
SCLC tumor marker; elevated in ~60% of SCLC
SCLC-specific tumor marker; more specific than NSE

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Autoimmune encephalitis overlap; if cognitive or autonomic features prominent
If initial antibodies negative but paraneoplastic syndrome suspected
Paraproteinemic neuropathy screen in atypical cases
Autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy if prominent autonomic features
Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration overlap with LEMS
If diagnosis uncertain; rule out inflammatory myopathy
Familial hemiplegic migraine/episodic ataxia with calcium channelopathy overlap; very rare

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h of diagnosis; primary malignancy screen
Essential/First-line.target: No lung mass, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, or thymoma

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate; initial screen for lung mass
Essential/First-line.target: No mass lesion, no hilar adenopathy

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 1-2 weeks of diagnosis; most sensitive for occult SCLC if CT chest negative; recommended for all LEMS patients
Essential/First-line.target: No FDG-avid lesion; SCLC can be very small and CT-occult
Normal sinus rhythm; no QTc prolongation

Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.item: Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) - low rate (2-3 Hz) (CPT 95937)
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.timing: During workup; test multiple nerves including proximal muscles
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.target: Decremental response >10% at 2-3 Hz (similar to MG but typically more pronounced; test hand and shoulder muscles)

Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.item: Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) - high rate (20-50 Hz) (CPT 95937)
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.timing: Immediately after low-rate RNS; DIAGNOSTIC hallmark of LEMS
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.target: Incremental response >100% (often >200%) at high-frequency stimulation; this distinguishes LEMS from MG
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.contraindications: Pacemaker (relative); painful - consider post-exercise facilitation instead

Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.timing: 10 seconds of maximal voluntary contraction then immediate repeat CMAP; preferred over high-rate RNS (less painful)
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.target: >100% increment in CMAP amplitude post-exercise; characteristic of presynaptic NMJ disorder

Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.timing: Before RNS; record resting CMAP amplitudes in multiple nerves
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.target: Low resting CMAP amplitudes (typically <5 mV in hand muscles); hallmark of LEMS

Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.timing: Complete electrodiagnostic evaluation; rule out concurrent neuropathy/myopathy
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.target: Low CMAP amplitudes at rest; normal sensory responses; no active denervation (unless cancer-related neuropathy)

Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.timing: If RNS non-diagnostic; increased jitter with improvement at higher firing rates (opposite of MG pattern)
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.target: Increased jitter that improves with increased firing rate (presynaptic pattern)

Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.timing: If autonomic symptoms present; quantifies autonomic involvement
Electrodiagnostic & Specialized Studies.target: Abnormal sudomotor, cardiovagal, or adrenergic responses; supports LEMS diagnosis

Cancer Screening Protocol.timing: If initial CT chest negative and clinical suspicion high (DELTA-P >=2)
Every 6 months for 2 years if DELTA-P >=3 and initial PET negative
Every 6 months for 2 years from diagnosis; then annually for 2 more years (total 4 years screening)
Cancer Screening Protocol.target: No new lung nodules or mass

Cancer Screening Protocol.timing: If neurological symptoms suggest brain metastases or paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration
If CT/PET shows suspicious pulmonary lesion
As part of comprehensive malignancy screen
If no lung cancer found; screen for other malignancies

Cancer Screening Protocol.item: Deep tendon reflex testing (pre- and post-exercise)
Cancer Screening Protocol.target: Hyporeflexia or areflexia at rest that improves after 10 sec maximal contraction (Lambert sign); pathognomonic for LEMS
Proximal weakness legs > arms; hip flexors and quadriceps most affected; may improve briefly with initial contraction
Reduced grip at baseline; may improve after initial maximal effort (post-exercise facilitation)

Cancer Screening Protocol.timing: At presentation and serially if respiratory symptoms

Cancer Screening Protocol.target: No orthostatic hypotension (drop >20 systolic or >10 diastolic on standing)
Normal pupillary responses; sluggish pupils may suggest autonomic involvement

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute LEMS exacerbation with significant functional impairment; rapid symptom control; pre-treatment or perioperative optimization

Ivig 1 g/kg IV daily x2 days
Ivig 2 g/kg IV divided over 2-5 days

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Pre-infusion: IgA level, renal function, CBC; during: vital signs q15 min first hour then q1h; headache; aseptic meningitis; thrombosis risk; renal function post-infusion

dosing.instructions: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; exchange 1-1.5 plasma volumes per session every other day; albumin replacement preferred

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP during exchange; electrolytes (Ca, K, Mg); coagulation studies; fibrinogen; line site infection; hypotension

Acute/Emergent.indication: Volume resuscitation for orthostatic hypotension from autonomic dysfunction

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: First-line symptomatic treatment for LEMS; enhances presynaptic acetylcholine release by blocking potassium channels; improves strength and autonomic symptoms

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg per dose every 3-5 days; usual effective dose 15-20 mg TID-QID; max 80 mg/day (max 20 mg per single dose); take with food

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Seizure history (lowers seizure threshold); concurrent use of drugs that lower seizure threshold; QT prolongation
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG at baseline and after dose changes; seizure precautions; QTc monitoring; paresthesias (perioral, digital); GI upset

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Alternative formulation of amifampridine for LEMS; enhances presynaptic acetylcholine release by blocking potassium channels; improves strength and autonomic symptoms

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg per dose every 3-5 days; usual effective dose 15-20 mg TID-QID; max 80 mg/day (max 20 mg per single dose); take with food

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Seizure history (lowers seizure threshold); concurrent use of drugs that lower seizure threshold; QT prolongation
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG at baseline and after dose changes; seizure precautions; QTc monitoring; paresthesias (perioral, digital); GI upset

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunctive symptomatic treatment; enhances postsynaptic acetylcholine effect; less effective in LEMS than in MG but may provide modest additional benefit when combined with 3,4-DAP

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg TID; increase by 30 mg per dose every 2-3 days; usual effective dose 60 mg q4-6h; max 120 mg per dose; less effective as monotherapy in LEMS than MG

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Cholinergic side effects: diarrhea, cramping, salivation, bradycardia

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Refractory dry mouth from autonomic dysfunction not responsive to 3,4-DAP; off-label use

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg daily; may increase to 2 mg daily; used off-label for autonomic dry mouth

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Orthostatic hypotension from autonomic dysfunction in LEMS

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5 mg TID; titrate by 2.5 mg per dose every 1-2 weeks; max 10 mg TID; avoid dosing within 4 hours of bedtime

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Supine hypertension; urinary retention; severe organic heart disease; pheochromocytoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Supine BP (check 1 hour after first dose); avoid supine position for 4h after dosing

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Orthostatic hypotension refractory to midodrine; volume expansion

dosing.instructions: Start 0.1 mg daily; may increase to 0.2 mg daily; max 0.3 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Electrolytes (hypokalemia); weight; BP; edema; supine hypertension

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Constipation from autonomic dysfunction in LEMS

dosing.instructions: 17 g (1 capful) dissolved in 8 oz liquid once daily; adjust frequency to bowel response

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Bowel habits; electrolytes if prolonged use

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Constipation from autonomic dysfunction; adjunct to osmotic laxative

dosing.instructions: 8.6-17.2 mg PO qHS; may increase to BID if needed; max 34.4 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Bowel habits; avoid long-term use if possible

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Dry eyes and dry mouth from autonomic dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Artificial tears q2-4h PRN for dry eyes; saliva substitute spray or lozenges PRN for dry mouth

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Erectile dysfunction from autonomic dysfunction in LEMS

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO 1 hour before sexual activity; may increase to 50-100 mg; max 100 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Concurrent nitrates (CONTRAINDICATED); severe cardiovascular disease; recent stroke/MI within 6 months
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BP; cardiac status; vision changes; priapism

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Autoimmune LEMS (A-LEMS) with inadequate response to 3,4-DAP alone; bridge to steroid-sparing agent; NOT first-line for P-LEMS (treat cancer first)

dosing.instructions: Start 10-20 mg daily; increase by 10 mg every 5-7 days to 0.5-1 mg/kg/day; maintain 4-8 weeks then taper by 5-10 mg/month to lowest effective dose

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; psychosis history
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Glucose; BP; mood/sleep; weight; bone density; GI prophylaxis

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Chronic immunomodulation for LEMS with ongoing functional impairment despite 3,4-DAP and oral immunotherapy

Ivig 1 g/kg IV daily x2 days
Ivig 2 g/kg IV divided over 2-5 days

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: Steroid-sparing agent for A-LEMS; long-term immunosuppression to reduce VGCC antibody production; onset 6-18 months

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; increase by 50 mg every 1-2 weeks to target 2-3 mg/kg/day (typically 150-250 mg/day); onset 6-18 months

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.pretreatment: TPMT genotype/activity BEFORE starting (mandatory); CBC; LFTs; hepatitis B/C screen; TB test
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.contraindications: TPMT deficiency (homozygous); concurrent allopurinol (reduce dose by 75%); pregnancy (relative); active infection
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.monitoring: TPMT genotype before starting; CBC q1-2 weeks during titration then monthly; LFTs monthly; amylase/lipase if abdominal pain; lymphocyte count target 600-1000

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: Steroid-sparing agent for A-LEMS; alternative to azathioprine; onset 6-12 months

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; increase to 1000 mg BID after 2 weeks; target 2000-3000 mg/day; onset 6-12 months

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.pretreatment: CBC; LFTs; hepatitis B/C screen; pregnancy test (females); TB test
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.contraindications: Pregnancy (Category D - teratogenic); concurrent azathioprine; active infection
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.monitoring: CBC q2 weeks x 3 months then monthly; LFTs; GI side effects (diarrhea, nausea); lymphopenia; REMS pregnancy prevention

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: Refractory A-LEMS not responding to conventional immunosuppressants; may be used earlier in severe cases; less evidence than in MG but reported efficacy

dosing.instructions: 375 mg/m2 IV weekly x 4 weeks; OR 1000 mg IV x 2 doses 14 days apart; re-dose when CD19/CD20 recover or clinical worsening; onset 3-6 months

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.pretreatment: HBV serology (HBsAg, anti-HBc, anti-HBs); hepatitis C screen; HIV test; CBC; immunoglobulins; TB test; vaccinations up to date
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.contraindications: Active hepatitis B; active infection; severe immunodeficiency; PML history
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.monitoring: CD19/CD20 counts q3-6 months; immunoglobulins q6 months; PML risk (very rare); infusion reactions (premedicate with acetaminophen, diphenhydramine, methylprednisolone)

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: Alternative steroid-sparing agent for A-LEMS; faster onset than azathioprine (2-6 months)

dosing.instructions: Start 2-3 mg/kg/day divided BID; target trough 100-150 ng/mL; onset 2-6 months

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.pretreatment: Renal function; BP; electrolytes; hepatitis screen; TB test
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; renal impairment; concurrent nephrotoxic drugs
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.monitoring: Trough levels; renal function q2 weeks then monthly; BP; electrolytes (K, Mg); lipids; gingival hyperplasia; hirsutism

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: Severe refractory LEMS not responding to other immunosuppressants; reserved for life-threatening or disabling disease

dosing.instructions: Pulse IV 500-1000 mg/m2 monthly x 6 months; OR oral 1-2 mg/kg/day; reserved for refractory cases; MESNA uroprotection with IV dosing

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.pretreatment: CBC; renal function; hepatitis screen; pregnancy test; fertility counseling
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.contraindications: Pregnancy; active infection; bone marrow suppression; hemorrhagic cystitis history
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.monitoring: CBC weekly during treatment; urinalysis (hemorrhagic cystitis); fertility counseling; malignancy risk

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: Standard first-line for SCLC in P-LEMS; treatment of underlying malignancy is the primary therapy for paraneoplastic LEMS; neurological symptoms often improve with cancer treatment

dosing.orderSentence: Oncology-directed chemotherapy (cisplatin/etoposide) Per oncology protocol IV

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.monitoring: Neuromuscular function during treatment; FVC if respiratory symptoms; electrolytes; renal function; myelosuppression

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: Limited-stage SCLC with or without concurrent chemotherapy; palliative radiation for extensive-stage

doseOptions.orderSentence: Radiation therapy (SCLC) Per radiation oncology protocol EXT

dosing.instructions: Concurrent chemoradiation for limited stage; palliative for extensive stage; prophylactic cranial irradiation per oncology
dosing.orderSentence: Radiation therapy (SCLC) Per radiation oncology protocol EXT

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.indication: SCLC maintenance (atezolizumab, durvalumab); CRITICAL WARNING: may worsen LEMS or trigger myasthenic crisis; only under joint neuro-oncology management

doseOptions.orderSentence: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (with extreme caution) Per oncology protocol IV

dosing.instructions: Per oncology; MUST be administered with close neuromuscular monitoring; have IVIg/PLEX available
dosing.orderSentence: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (with extreme caution) Per oncology protocol IV

Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.pretreatment: Baseline FVC; neuromuscular assessment; joint neuro-oncology plan
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.contraindications: Pre-existing myasthenic crisis; uncontrolled LEMS; use only with neuromuscular specialist co-management
Disease-Modifying / Immunosuppressive Th.monitoring: FVC before each cycle; MG-ADL equivalent assessment; creatine kinase; troponin (myocarditis); monitor for rapid neurological deterioration

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist referral for diagnosis confirmation, treatment planning, and long-term management of LEMS
Oncology referral for cancer screening and management in all LEMS patients (mandatory given ~60% paraneoplastic association)
Pulmonology referral for respiratory function monitoring if FVC declining or significant weakness
Thoracic surgery referral if lung mass identified on imaging
Radiation oncology referral if SCLC confirmed for treatment planning
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation if dysphagia or bulbar symptoms present
Physical therapy for proximal strengthening, gait training, and fall prevention given proximal leg weakness
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation and energy conservation strategies
Urology referral for erectile dysfunction management if not responsive to first-line treatment
Gastroenterology referral for refractory constipation from autonomic dysfunction
Psychiatry/Psychology referral for depression, anxiety, and adjustment to chronic diagnosis with cancer risk
Social work consult for insurance navigation, disability evaluation, and cancer support resources
Pain management referral for chronic pain from sustained weakness or paraneoplastic neuropathy
Palliative care referral for P-LEMS with advanced malignancy for goals of care discussion and symptom management
Infusion center coordination for IVIg or rituximab scheduling
Smoking cessation program referral given strong association between LEMS and SCLC in tobacco users
Cardiology referral if autonomic dysfunction includes cardiac arrhythmias or significant orthostatic hypotension

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if difficulty breathing, worsening weakness preventing walking, or inability to swallow (may indicate LEMS crisis or cancer progression)
Return to ED if new severe weakness, falls, or inability to rise from chair (proximal weakness progression)
Take 3,4-diaminopyridine (amifampridine) exactly as prescribed; do NOT exceed 20 mg per single dose or 80 mg/day (seizure risk)
Take 3,4-diaminopyridine with food to reduce GI side effects (nausea, abdominal discomfort)
Report any seizures, tingling around the mouth, or numbness in fingers immediately (may indicate 3,4-DAP toxicity)
Carry LEMS medical alert identification at all times (anesthesia and medication precautions critical)
Provide LEMS medication list to ALL healthcare providers (emergency, dental, surgical) - many medications worsen neuromuscular junction disorders
Attend ALL scheduled cancer screening appointments even if feeling well (cancer may develop years after LEMS diagnosis)
Report any new cough, weight loss, fatigue, chest pain, or hemoptysis immediately (may indicate lung cancer)
Rise slowly from sitting or lying position to avoid falls from orthostatic hypotension (stand at bed/chair edge for 30 seconds before walking)
Increase fluid and salt intake to help manage orthostatic hypotension from autonomic dysfunction (unless restricted by other conditions)
Plan activities for times of best strength; use energy conservation techniques; rest between tasks
Do NOT stop immunosuppressant medications abruptly without physician guidance (disease flare risk)
Avoid extreme heat, hot baths, and saunas (may worsen weakness)
Report excessive dry mouth, constipation, or urinary symptoms to neurologist (autonomic dysfunction may require treatment adjustment)
Avoid alcohol (potentiates weakness and interacts with medications)
Understand that LEMS symptoms may improve if underlying cancer is successfully treated (for P-LEMS patients)
Stop smoking immediately if current smoker (reduces cancer risk and may slow disease progression)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation mandatory given strong association between LEMS, SCLC, and tobacco use (reduces ongoing cancer risk)
Low-impact exercise (swimming, stationary bike, yoga) to maintain strength and mobility without overexertion given proximal weakness
Energy conservation with scheduled rest periods to manage fatigue and optimize function throughout the day
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards given proximal leg weakness and orthostatic hypotension (secure rugs, install grab bars, adequate lighting)
Compression stockings (waist-high, 30-40 mmHg) for orthostatic hypotension management from autonomic dysfunction
Elevate head of bed 10-20 degrees to reduce nocturnal supine hypertension while managing orthostatic hypotension
Increase dietary fluid intake to 2-3 L/day and liberal salt intake (unless contraindicated) for orthostatic hypotension
High-fiber diet with adequate hydration for constipation management from autonomic dysfunction
Regular dental care and oral hygiene given xerostomia (dry mouth) from autonomic dysfunction (increased caries risk)
Vitamin D supplementation if deficient (1000-2000 IU daily) to support immune function and bone health, especially if on chronic steroids
Calcium supplementation (1000-1200 mg daily) if on chronic corticosteroids for bone protection
Annual influenza vaccination (inactivated form) and COVID-19 vaccination as recommended; avoid live vaccines if on immunosuppression
Aspiration precautions including thickened liquids and chin tuck positioning if dysphagia present from bulbar involvement

Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.details: Unpredictable response in LEMS; may have prolonged block
Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.safe alternative (if applicable): Non-depolarizing agents at markedly reduced dose with sugammadex available

Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.details: Exaggerated and prolonged response; use 1/10 to 1/5 normal dose if absolutely necessary
Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.safe alternative (if applicable): Sugammadex for reversal of rocuronium; neuromuscular monitoring with TOF mandatory

Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.details: Impair presynaptic ACh release; can precipitate respiratory failure
Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.safe alternative (if applicable): Non-aminoglycoside antibiotics based on culture sensitivity

Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.details: NMJ blocking effect; FDA warning for neuromuscular disorders
May worsen weakness; impair NMJ transmission; worsen orthostatic hypotension
Directly antagonize VGCC; may significantly worsen LEMS by further reducing calcium influx at nerve terminal
Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.safe alternative (if applicable): Amlodipine (lower risk); ACE inhibitors; avoid verapamil/diltiazem specifically

Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.details: Inhibits presynaptic ACh release; can precipitate crisis
Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.safe alternative (if applicable): Avoid except life-threatening hypomagnesemia; ICU monitoring required

Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.details: May worsen paraneoplastic neurological syndromes; can trigger myasthenic crisis; use only with joint neuro-oncology management
Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.safe alternative (if applicable): If required for cancer treatment, close neuromuscular monitoring mandatory

Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.details: Blocks presynaptic ACh release; CONTRAINDICATED in LEMS
Medications to Avoid or Use with Caution.safe alternative (if applicable): Physical therapy; oral medications for spasticity

differential.features: Fatigable weakness that WORSENS with exertion (opposite of LEMS); ptosis and diplopia prominent (rare in LEMS); normal or brisk reflexes; no autonomic dysfunction; no cancer association (except thymoma)
differential.tests: AChR/MuSK antibodies positive; RNS shows decrement at low-rate WITHOUT significant increment at high-rate; CMAP amplitudes normal at rest

differential.features: Acute onset descending paralysis; dilated/fixed pupils; recent ingestion of contaminated food or wound; autonomic dysfunction present; NO prior NMJ disease
differential.tests: Stool/serum botulinum toxin assay; EMG shows BSAP pattern with incremental response similar to LEMS but acute onset

differential.features: Proximal weakness without fatigability; elevated CK (often >1000); skin findings in DM (heliotrope rash, Gottron papules); no autonomic dysfunction; no NMJ abnormalities on RNS
differential.tests: CK; myositis antibody panel; EMG shows myopathic pattern (no NMJ findings); muscle biopsy

differential.features: Slowly progressive; finger flexor and quadriceps weakness (asymmetric); no autonomic dysfunction; older males; no NMJ findings
differential.tests: CK mildly elevated; EMG shows mixed myopathic/neurogenic pattern; muscle biopsy (rimmed vacuoles); anti-cN1A antibody

differential.features: Progressive weakness with fasciculations; UMN signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski); no autonomic dysfunction; no fatigability pattern; EMG shows active denervation
differential.tests: EMG/NCS: active denervation, fasciculations, normal NMJ studies; no VGCC antibodies

differential.features: Progressive proximal and distal weakness; hyporeflexia/areflexia (but NO post-exercise facilitation); sensory involvement prominent; elevated CSF protein
differential.tests: NCS: demyelinating pattern; CSF protein elevated; no VGCC antibodies; no RNS increment

differential.features: Acute ascending weakness; areflexia; post-infectious; no autonomic facilitation; respiratory failure more common
differential.tests: CSF albuminocytologic dissociation; NCS: demyelinating or axonal pattern; no VGCC antibodies

differential.features: Proximal weakness with myalgias; delayed relaxation of reflexes (NOT facilitation); fatigue; weight gain; cold intolerance
differential.tests: TSH elevated; free T4 low; CK may be elevated; EMG non-specific; no NMJ findings

differential.features: Fatigue and weakness; orthostatic hypotension; hyperpigmentation; electrolyte abnormalities (hyperkalemia, hyponatremia); weight loss
differential.tests: Morning cortisol; ACTH stimulation test; electrolytes; no NMJ findings

differential.features: Prominent autonomic dysfunction; orthostatic hypotension; urinary dysfunction; NO proximal weakness pattern; NO NMJ findings on RNS
differential.tests: Autonomic function testing; brain MRI (MSA: hot cross bun sign); no VGCC antibodies; normal RNS

differential.features: Childhood onset; family history; seronegative; specific gene mutations; may have presynaptic, synaptic, or postsynaptic defect
differential.tests: Genetic testing (CMS gene panel); no VGCC antibodies; specific RNS patterns depend on CMS type

differential.features: Proximal weakness; areflexia; childhood or adult onset; fasciculations; no autonomic dysfunction; no NMJ findings
differential.tests: Genetic testing (SMN1 deletion); EMG shows anterior horn cell disease pattern; no VGCC antibodies

differential.features: Ataxia rather than proximal weakness; may coexist with LEMS in ~15% of cases; anti-Purkinje cell antibodies
differential.tests: PCA-Tr/DNER, Yo, Hu antibodies; brain MRI showing cerebellar atrophy; VGCC may be positive (overlap)

differential.features: Temporal correlation with offending medication (aminoglycosides, calcium channel blockers); reversible on drug withdrawal
differential.tests: Drug history review; NMJ studies normalize after drug discontinuation; no VGCC antibodies

evidence.recommendation: P/Q-type VGCC antibodies diagnostic for LEMS (~85-90% sensitivity)
evidence.source: Lennon VA et al. N Engl J Med 1995; 332:1467-1474

evidence.recommendation: LEMS association with SCLC (~60% paraneoplastic)
evidence.source: Titulaer MJ et al. J Clin Oncol 2011; 29:902-908

evidence.recommendation: DELTA-P score for paraneoplastic risk stratification
evidence.source: Titulaer MJ et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2011; 82:1222-1228

evidence.recommendation: SOX1 antibody as SCLC biomarker in LEMS (~64% sensitivity)
evidence.source: Titulaer MJ et al. J Neuroimmunol 2009; 210:78-82

evidence.recommendation: Repetitive nerve stimulation: >100% increment at high-rate diagnostic for presynaptic NMJ disorder
evidence.source: Oh SJ et al. Muscle Nerve 2005; 32:549-556

evidence.recommendation: Low resting CMAP amplitudes as hallmark of LEMS
evidence.source: Sanders DB. Ann N Y Acad Sci 2003; 998:500-508

evidence.recommendation: Post-exercise facilitation (>100% CMAP increment) equivalent to high-rate RNS
evidence.source: Oh SJ et al. Muscle Nerve 2005; 32:549-556
